title: Saltford Walks

images.title: Philip Halling / Saltford Marina
images.caption: Narrowboats in the Saltford Marina. The marina is just off the River Avon near the weir.

images.title: Dr Duncan Pepper / Weir at Saltford
images.caption: View of the weir near the start of the walk. The canalized river Avon at Saltford beside the Riverside Inn looking downstream towards Keynsham.

images.title: Pierre Terre / River Avon above Saltford
images.caption: River Avon above Saltford. Houseboats moored on the left bank above the village. Here the GWR continues NW as the river swings away north; spot the train above the second boat.

images.title: Rick Crowley / Medieval Pond in Saltford
images.caption: Medieval Pond in Saltford. One of a few medieval ponds situated across the fields from the back of Saltford Manor. In those days meat was not allowed to be eaten on a Friday or a Saturday, hence these were probably stocked with pike and perch, and believed to be tended by monks.

images.title: Derek Harper / Bridge over Bristol & Bath Railway Path
images.caption: Bridge over Bristol and Bath Railway Path above the village. An impressive bridge, whose bluish and purple bricks are gradually being covered in ivy, that carries a track and footpath from Avon Lane across the cycle path (NCN 4).

images.title: Maurice Pullin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Avon Valley Country Park. Seen from Pixash Lane railway bridge. Kelston Round Hill ST7167 is on the skyline to the right with its clump of trees hidden in the low cloud.

images.title: Sharon Loxton / The river Chew
images.caption: The river Chew. A view of the river Chew to the south of Keynsham. In spite of the dry weather the river looks to be bank full, and seems to be carrying a lot of sediment.

images.title: Hugh Llewelyn from Keynsham, UK, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Saltford Manor. This is the oldest continuously occupied Manor House (12th Century Norman - possibly 1148) in England. It was remodelled in the 17th Century.

description: This village near Bath is located in a lovely spot, next to a canalized section of the River Avon. Saltford is also notable for its 12th century Manor House which claims to be the oldest continuously occupied dwelling in England. This route from the village uses parts of the Bristol and Bath Railway Path , the River Avon Trail and the Two Rivers Way to create a circular walk through the surrounding area. On the way you'll visit Avon Valley Country Park and the neighbouring town of Keynsham . The walk starts on the River Avon, just to the east of the village. Here you can pick up the Bristol and Bath Railway Path and follow the shared cycling and walking trail north along a disused railway line. This will take you up to the river, passing the Avon Valley Country Park on the way. The park has a number of attractions including surfaced country walks, a boating lake, play areas for children, a small petting zoo and a miniature railway. This route picks up the River Avon Trail and follows the path west towards Keynsham. Here you can pick up the Two Rivers Way and follow another footpath south along the River Chew to Chewton Keynsham. The route then turns east to follow country lanes back into Saltford.
